description.narrative:
International Youth Foundation (IYF) har ansökt om finansiering av Sveriges ambassad/Sida på 25 500 000 SEK (3 000 000 USD) för att utföra projektet Zimbabwe: Works Phase II under perioden 2015-2017 (3 år).
Interventionen syftar till att förbättra ungdomars egenmakt, och särskilt bland unga kvinnor, för att bidra till och dra nytta av den ekonomiska tillväxten i Zimbabwe genom att: 1. höja implementeringspartners kapacitet att bättre kunna hjälpa ungdomar och integrera jämställdhetsfrågor, 2. höja ungdomars kunskap om entreprenörskap genom utbildning och mentorskap, samt arbeta med mikrofinansinstitutioner (Micro Finance Institutions, MFIs) för att uppnå högre ekonomisk integration bland ungdomar, 3. arbeta med ungdomar (särskilt unga kvinnor) och arbetsgivare för att förbättra ungdomars möjligheter till anställning. International Youth Foundation (IYF), Zimbabwes fältkontor samt huvudkontor (Washington DC), kommer att arbeta med zimbabwiska partnerorganisationer för att genomföra detta program. IYF Zimbabwe kommer att identifiera och bedöma blivande partners, med finansiella givares vetorätt innan slutgiltigt godkännande och överenskommelse med IYF HQ (Washington DC). Alla zimbabwiska partners utbetalningar kommer att komma direkt från International Youth Foundation (IYF) i Washington DC.
Interventionens totala budget är 65 610 569 SEK (7 938 099 USD), varav 2 miljoner kronor kommer från International Youth Foundation (IYF) egna medel; återstoden av insatsen finansieras gemensamt av USAID med 8 139 300 SEK (1 miljon USD), DFID med 30 058 174 SEK (3 692 968 USD) och Sveriges ambassad med 25 500 000 SEK (3 000 000) {Notera att DFID:s bidrag omfattar 1 miljon USD till en plan för kreditgaranti - DCA}. DFID har undertecknat ett samförståndsavtal med, och kommer att betala ut medel genom, USAID. USAID, i egenskap av ledande givare, kommer att skriva avtal med International Youth Foundation (IYF).

International Youth Foundation (IYF) has applied to the Embassy of Sweden/Sida for funding of SEK25,500,000 (US$3 million) to carry out the Zimbabwe:Works Phase II project during the period 2015-2017 ( 3 years).
The intervention aims at improvement the broad empowerment of youth, and particularly young women, to contribute towards and benefit from economic growth in Zimbabwe by 1. building the capacity of local implementing partners to be better able to serve young people and mainstream gender equality issues, 2. building the young people entrepreneurship skills through training & mentorship, as well as working with Micro Finance Institutions (MFIs) to achieve higher youth financial inclussion, 3. work with young people (particularly young women) and employers to improve the youths' employability. International Youth Foundation (IYF), Zimbabwe Field Office and HQ (Washington DC), will work with Zimbabwean partner organizations to implement this program. IYF Zimbabwe will identify and assess the prospective partners, with funding donors exercise veto powers before final approval and contracting with the IYF HQ (Washington DC). All Zimbabwean partner funds disbursements will come directly from International Youth Foundation (IYF) in Washington DC.
The intervention's total budget is SEK65,610,569 (US$7,938,099), out of which International Youth Foundation (IYF) is putting about SEK 2 million of its own funds; the remaining balance of contributions is co-funded thus USAid SEK8,139,300 (US$1 million), DFiD SEK30,058,174 (US$3,692,968) and Embassy of Sweden SEK25,500,000 (US$3 million) {N.B. the DFiD contribution includes $1million contribution to a credit guarantee scheme - DCA}. DFiD signed an MOU with, and will disburse funds through, USAid. USAid, as the lead donor, will contract with the International Youth Foundation (IYF).
To achieve broad empowerment of youth, and particularly young women, to contribute towards and benefit from economic growth in Zimbabwe

description.narrative: The Zimbabwe:Works (Z:W) Phase II project aimed at strengthening job skills and improving the employment and self-employment status of young Zimbabweans, particularly young women, to contribute towards and benefit from economic growth in the country. At the end of the project, young people benefited from the following Z:W training services and products: - 14 950 youth (68 percent women) gained improved entrepreneurship and business skills, with 9 029 of these youth (68 percent women) trained in financial literacy. - 3 681 (73 percent women) accessed finance from microfinance institutions, which resulted in an incremental net profit of US$21 256 957 earned from business expansion and growth and an additional net profit of US$2 899 852 earned as incremental income by employees of the youth businesses. - 1 087 youth (56 percent women) improved their technical and vocational skills. - 5 218 youth (61 percent women) were equipped with improved work readiness and life skills for professional and personal growth. - 1 814 youth (62 percent women) had enhanced employability through their participation in internships and mentorships; and 80 percent (1 458) of the young people in internships transitioned into full time employment. - Incremental annual income of $7 014 674 was earned by interns who successfully accessed formal employment. - Improved youth resilience for both men and women.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
